DUPONT YERKES PLANT EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

INTRODUCTION

At the DuPont Yerkes Plant, we use a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.  This RMP document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:

o Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies
o Facility description and substance regulated by Risk Management Plan (RMP) regulation
o Worst-case and alternative-case release scenarios
o Five-year accident history for accidental releases of RMP chemicals
o General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps
o Overview of our emergency response program
o Planned facility changes to improve safety and prevent accidental releases 


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The DuPont Yerkes plant is committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes in a safe and responsible manner.  A guiding principle, as stated in our Yerkes Vision Statement, is "We will secure our future by.... advancing our Core Values of Safety, Ethics, Environmental Stewardship and Respectful Treatment of People", both at our facility and in our community.

The DuPont Yerkes Plant adheres to Corporate policies.  These policies are embodied in numerous Safety Health & Environmental and Engineering Standards, which apply globally.  These standards can be summarized as follows:

o All Safety and Environmental incidents are preventable.
o Total Committment to Zero Incidents.
o All employees and contractors are responsible for their safety.


FACILITY DESCRIPTION AND SUBSTANCE REGULATED BY RMP REGULATION

The Yerkes plant covers approximately 100 acres in a highly industrialized section of the Town of Tonawanda, NY.  The facility is fully fenced and monitored 24 hours a day by a

security force.  Various products have been manufactured on the site since 1921.  Currently, the site consists of two manufacturing businesses:

o Tedlar(R); polyvinyl fluoride films
o Corian(R); sheet and shape filled acrylic building materials

The EPA has identified VINYL FLUORIDE (VF), which is flammable, as a chemical at Yerkes which has the potential to cause significant offsite consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release.

WORST-CASE AND ALTERNATIVE-CASE RELEASE SCENARIOS

Following are brief summaries of the Worst and Alternate case scenarios, including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario:

Worst-case Release Scenario: Vinyl Fluoride, Regulated Flammable Chemical

The worst-case release scenario is a Vinyl Fluoride storage tank failure, with no mitigation assumed.  A release if ignited could result in a vapor cloud explosion that with an off-site impact but no public receptors.  A release is unlikely due to the construction and high-integrity design of tanks / associated equipment, and dual water deluge / emergency tower venting systems.

Alternative Release Scenario Vinyl Fluoride, Regulated Flammable Chemical

The alternate-case release scenario is being updated in this submittal to a different scenario.  The old alternate scenario was a flex hose failure during unloading of Vinyl Fluoride from a tank truck to a storage tank, with no passive mitigation assumed.  A release if ignited could result in a flash fire.  This scenario has changed to highly unlikely because of the addition since last filing of a liquid hose break away coupling, which will automatically close if the hose is disconnected during transfer.  This new mitigation, in addition to the pre-existing tank truck excess flow valve, automatic shutdown equipment, procedures, preventive maintenance of the hoses, use of checklists and the construction and high-integrity design

of tank trucks and associated unloading / transfer equipment all reduce the possibility of an unloading hose failure to very low risk.

The new alternate-case release scenario is the most likly scenario from the 2012 cyclic Process Hazards Review "2012 VF Unloading and Storage", scenario 1f.  This would be a 1/4 inch hole in either the unloading flex hose or any part of a storage tank or piping.  The leak was assumed to impinge on the ground to maximize the impact in the area.  This could result in a vapor cloud fire.  The details of this scenario are available in the PHA report.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY FOR ACCIDENTAL RELEASES OF RMP CHEMICALS

Within the past five years, the Tedlar(R); process has had no accidental release that caused offsite impacts provided in the Risk Management Plan regulation, (40 CFR 68.10(b)(1)).

Records are kept for all Serious Incidents (non-standard operations) that occur at our facility.  For every Serious Incident, we conduct a formal incident investigation to identify and correct the root causes of the event.  

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND VINYL FLUORIDE SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

Yerkes accidental release prevention programs and contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the hazards that are posed to our employees, the public, and the environment by our use of Vinyl Fluoride.  The site takes a systematic, proactive approach to prevent accidental releases of Vinyl Fluoride.  The process to react Vinyl Fluoride to form polyvinyl fluoride follows the requirements of the DuPont Corporate Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.  This standard includes and embraces the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR Part 68.  Yerkes management systems address each of the key features of the layers of protection necessary for a successful prevention program including:

o Equipment Specifications 
  * Follow industry specific standards
  * Document design specifications and calculations for

storage tanks, piping, safety relief valves and other Process Safety  Management critical equipment
  * VF delivery tank trucks are equipped with an excess flow valve
  * Tank truck liquid unload hose has a break away coupling that would automatically close if connection is broken.
o Training
  * Operational, mechanical and contractor personnel working with or close to VF equipment are trained per OSHA and DOT standards
  * Operators working with VF equipment are HAZWOPER trained (29 CFR1910.120).
o Operating And Safety Procedures
  * Changes to procedures use the management of change procedure per OSHA standard
  * Operating procedures are reviewed and verified by Job Cycle Checks
  * Specific checklists and/or procedures for PSM critical operations are maintained
  * PSM critical operating procedures are authorized yearly per OSHA standard
  * Pre-start up safety reviews are conducted on new or modified equipment
  * A cargo tank truck inspection checklist is used before Vinyl Fluoride unloading begins
  * Remote continuous ambient Vinyl Fluoride monitoring is performed
  * Operators observe VF unloading operations 100% of the process
 o Maintenance Inspection Systems
  * All PSM critical equipment is set up on a periodic inspection frequency
  * Mechanical work plans are reviewed via the work order system
  * Tank trucks are dedicated and inspected and maintained per 49 CFR 180.407(c)
  * Preventative Maintenance (PM) is performed routinely on existing equipment
o Safety And Emergency Systems
  * Process hazards reviews are performed every 5 years per OSHA standard
  * Serious incident investigations are held for non-standard events to correct root cause
  * An emergency venting tower will convey Vinyl Fluoride away from the area to prevent a build up of flammable gas
  * Remote fail safe air operated valves can isolate the unloading operation, storage tanks and shut down operations
  * Tank farm and barricade are covered by dual 600 GPM

water deluge systems
  * Storage tanks and reactor vessel are continuously monitored for temperature and pressure and an alarm will sound if above standard conditions occur
  * A computerized work order system, that issues PMs, is used to track inspections of all VF hoses, flame arrestors, rupture disks and relief valves

OVERVIEW OF OUR EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Yerkes maintains an integrated emergency control plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.

The site program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, we coordinate our plan with the Town of Tonawanda, NY Emergency Services.  Our program can be summarized as follows:

o Tedlar(R); Specific Procedures
  * Emergency shutdown procedure for an uncontrolled reaction, explosion, or fire
  * Emergency shutdown for a VF leak inside the Polymer Area barricade
  * Emergency shutdown for a VF leak outside the Polymer Area barricade

o Yerkes Emergency Control Plan Overview
  * Plant fire alarm is sounded in area of emergency and emergency responders report
  * Disaster alarm sounded as needed and Emergency Control Plan activated
  * Central and Field Control Organizations report
  * Community emergency responders are notified as appropriate.

o External Resources
  * DuPont maintains a regional Transportation Emergency Response Team
  * Yerkes has contracts with external companies for emergency response assistance
  * Yerkes is a member of the local Hazardous Materials Advisory Council for mutual aid
  * Local fire departments
  * DuPont Yerkes is an active member of the Erie County Local Emergency Planning Committee

o Training and Preparation
  * Yerkes personnel receive emergency response training
  * Yerkes holds site emergency drills and participates in community drills
  * Community

and contract emergency responders tour the Yerkes Plant
  * Yerkes Risk Management Plan has been presented to Erie County LEPC
